summary: Email chain between a Senior Forensic Examiner (NY CART Coordinator) and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the status of forensic evidence extraction from devices in the Epstein case. The discussion covers delivery of materials, duplicate folders, zero-byte files, and the status of physically failed drives requiring specialist recovery.

persons.name: I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the extraction and delivery of digital evidence from devices in the Epstein case, answering questions about spreadsheets, duplicate folders, and zero-byte files.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Prosecutor following up on outstanding issues regarding the receipt and status of forensic evidence from devices in the Epstein case, asking specific questions about materials and extraction issues.

connections.person2: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Law enforcement forensic examiner providing evidence updates and technical explanations to the prosecuting attorney handling the Epstein case.

events.title: Evidence Status Update Email
events.description: Senior Forensic Examiner responds to prosecutor's questions about Epstein evidence, confirming final items were given to another person, explaining duplicate folders and zero-byte files.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: Previous Evidence Queries
events.description: Prosecutor sends questions about spreadsheet discrepancies, duplicate folders, and zero-byte files found in initial seven devices from Epstein case.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

locations: NYC (referenced in evidence item numbers like NYC024328, NYC027913)
keyFacts: Approximately 71,000 documents from the initial seven devices in the Epstein case were zero-byte (empty) files, which the forensic examiner stated is not unusual for recovery software to find.
Some drives from servers (NYC024376-380 and several in NYC024395) were still being processed, with some physically failed and requiring specialist recovery at FBI HQ, which could be a long process.
Duplicate folders (NYC024328, NYC024366, NYC024392) were provided on multiple discs, and clarification was needed on whether they contained new information.
The forensic examiner indicated final evidence items were given to another person (name redacted) for delivery to the prosecutor.
The correspondence is subject to a protective order covering specific paragraphs (7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17), indicating sensitive or restricted information.
